page.title: 15Pinvin
page.content:
Pinvin is really a suburb to the north of Pershore. It lies just over the Worcester-Evesham railway line, in fact closer to Pershore station than the centre of Pershore itself.
Pinvin lies on low marshy ground which was once owned by{King Penda.}It was primarily known as Penda's Fen which was subsequently corrupted to Pinvin.
The small church exhibits a late nineteenth century bellcote, a Norman doorway, a late Norman font, and a Jacobean pulpit. The thirteenth century wall paintings show the Crucifixion and the Adoration of the Magi.
